benzyltoluene. Reaction conditions: 250 °C, 1 atm., molar H12-BT:Pt ratio = 2000. Catalysts with 3 wt% Pt. a: catalysts P-modified at 300 °C (catalyst series 2). Ptred-P300/Al2O3 = catalyst 2-b* . b: catalysts P-modified at 600 °C (catalyst series 3). Pt-H3PO3/Al2O3 red. 600 °C = catalyst impregnated with H3PO3 and reduced at 600 °C. Unmodified Pt catalysts 1-a (red. 440 °C) and 1-b (red 600 °C). Error determined from repeated dehydrogenation experiments with different catalyst batches. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Methyl fluorene (MF) content in dependency of degree of dehydrogenation (DoDh) for unmodified Pt catalysts (catalysts 1-a and 1-b, reduced at 440 or 600 °C, respectively) and P-modified catalysts. Pt-P600/Al2O3: P-modification at 600 °C (catalyst 3-b). Pt-H3PO3/Al2O3: wet impregnation with H3PO3 with subsequent reduction at 600 °C. Reaction conditions: 250 °C, 1 atm, 15 g H12-BT, molar H12-BT:Pt ratio = 2000. Catalysts with 3 wt% Pt. Liquid samples analyzed via GC-FID. Error determined from repeated dehydrogenation experiments with different catalyst batches. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Dehydrogenation results from P-modified catalysts (300 °C, N2) including post-treatment (catalyst series 4). Reaction conditions: 250 °C, 1 atm., molar H12-BT:Pt ratio = 2000. Catalysts with 3 wt% Pt. a: Integral Pt-based H2 yields after 6 h of semi-batch dehydrogenation of perhydro benzyltoluene. b: Methyl fluorene (MF) content in dependency of degree of dehydrogenation (DoDh). Liquid samples analyzed via GC-FID. Error determined from repeated dehydrogenation experiments with different catalyst batches. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 a: STEM-EDX spectrum images of Pt catalyst P-modified at 600 °C (catalyst 3-b). b: Particle size distributions from HAADF-STEM-images of unmodified Pt catalyst reduced at 440 °C (catalyst 1-a) and 600 °C (catalyst 1-b). b: Particle size distributions from HAADF-STEM-images of catalysts from P-modification at 300 °C (catalyst 2-b) and 600 °C (catalyst 3-b). dVA = volume-area-mean particle size. Analysis of 150–200 particles per sample. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 XPS spectra of unmodified Pt catalyst (1-a) and after P-modification at 300 °C (2-b*, 2-b) and 600 °C (3-b). a: Pt4d line. b: P2p line. Vertical dashed and dotted lines are a guide for the eyes, indicating the position and shift of peak maxima. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 XPS spectra of unmodified Pt catalyst (1-a) and after P-modification at 300 °C (2-b) with post-treatment (4-b, 4-c) and P-modification at 600 °C (3-b). a: Pt4d line. b: P2p line. Vertical dashed and dotted lines are a guide for the eyes, indicating the position and shift of peak maxima. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 Solid state 31P CP MAS NMR spectra of P-modified Al2O3 support and Pt catalysts. a: Al2O3 support after different modification methods, temperatures and atmospheres. b: Pt catalysts after different modification methods, temperatures and atmospheres. H3PO3-impregnation and treatment in N2 (orange lines). H3PO3-impregnation and treatment in H2 (blue lines). P-modification by decomposition of NaH2PO2 (PH3) in N2 flow (green lines). Dashed line at 3 ppm (peak maximum of dried H3PO3/Al2O3). Fig. 7 Scheme 1 Reaction scheme of dehydrogenation of perhydro benzyltoluene (H12-BT) via intermediate formation of H6-BT. Egerlandstrasse 3 Erlangen 91058 Germany This study introduces a solvent-free gas-phase method for modifying Al₂O₃-supported platinum (3 wt%) catalysts with phosphorus (P) to enhance Pt dispersion and dehydrogenation activity. The process involves decomposing NaH₂PO₂ at 600 °C, releasing PH₃, interacting with Pt on the catalyst surface. P-modified catalysts showed up to a 24 % increase in activity for perhydro-benzyltoluene dehydrogenation within a P:Pt ratio of 0.6–2.6. Additionally, they exhibited high resistance to sintering, maintaining Pt particle sizes of ∼0.9 nm even at 600 °C. Characterization using CO chemisorption, STEM NMR, and XPS revealed that PH₃ deposits phosphorus on the catalyst, which then oxidizes via support lattice oxygen. At 600 °C, this oxidized phosphorus migrates to the support/metal interface, stabilizing Pt nanoparticles and preventing sintering. However, when the P:Pt ratio exceeds 2.6, excess phosphorus remains on the surface, deactivating active sites. This study highlights the role of POₓ species in stabilizing Pt nanoparticles and optimizing catalyst performance. It is mentioned in the manuscript. 1 Introduction In the future H2 economy, efficient catalysts for hydrogenation and dehydrogenation reactions will play a key role within the context of chemical hydrogen storage. Herein, platinum (Pt) nanoparticles that are supported on porous materials such as Al2O3, are one of the most used and powerful heterogeneous (de-)hydrogenation catalysts [1–4]. In those catalysts, achieving a high dispersion of small metal nanoparticles that is also stable under reaction conditions is especially challenging for high metal loadings (> 1 wt%) [5,6], but at the same time crucial for a high platinum surface area und therefore high catalytic activity. Metal as well as non-metal promotors are frequently added to further enhance the catalyst performance with regard to selectivity, stability and activity [7–11]. Doping of supported Pt catalysts with sulfur (S) or phosphorus (P) has been shown to enhance catalyst activity, e.g., in the dehydrogenation of perhydro dibenzyltoluene (H18-DBT), a relevant reaction in the context of hydrogen storage in liquid organic hydrogen carriers (LOHC). In these studies, S-modification of Pt/Al2O3 leads to a selective blockage of low coordinated Pt sites. 12 The simultaneous alteration of the electronic environment of Pt by S enables a facilitated desorption of the dehydrogenated product, which in turn improves both activity and selectivity of the catalyst [12,13]. Moreover, P-modification of Pt/Al2O3 catalysts by wet impregnation with H3PO3 investigated in a previous study results in enhanced H2 yields (increase by 18 % compared to the P-free counterpart) in the dehydrogenation of perhydro benzyltoluene (H12-BT). The high dehydrogenation activity of Pt-H3PO3/Al2O3 is also indicated by a higher content of the undesired side product methyl fluorene (MF) in the liquid phase, which is formed upon further deep dehydrogenation of the desired product benzyltoluene H0-BT ( Scheme 1). These Pt-H3PO3/Al2O3 catalysts further exhibit reduced Pt particle sizes below 1 nm with dispersion stabilized against sintering up to reduction temperatures of 900 °C. Thereby, Pt is conserved in its reduced Pt0 state, while oxidized P-species are present on the surface, even after H2 treatment and no formation of metal phosphide phases is observed [14]. Promoters such as S or P can be deposited on the catalyst surface e.g. by impregnation with a respective precursor. Successful P-doping of a Pt catalyst via impregnation with aqueous H3PO3 was shown in a previous study [14], however, further insights are necessary in order to elucidate the mechanism of phosphorus binding, and to understand the formed phosphorus species as well as its effect on the active metal. In the present study we aimed for an easy to implement gas phase P-modification approach with the aim of obtaining highly temperature stable and active dehydrogenation catalysts. Herein, the treatment of a Pt catalyst with a gaseous P precursor would allow for minimal chemical and structural changes by the omission of a solvent and stirrer. In the synthesis of transition metal phosphide catalysts, sodium hypophosphite (NaH2PO2) is a commonly used phosphorus precursor that does not require the use of a solvent [15–18]. Starting at 300 °C, NaH2PO2 decomposes to sodium phosphates and phosphites coupled with the release of gaseous PH3 [19]. This approach benefits from using a safe solid precursor and avoids the direct use of highly toxic PH3. When both the precursor and the respective catalytic material are placed in a gas-tight furnace, P-modification can then be initiated by increasing the temperature. In this study, we demonstrate that gas phase P-modification of Pt/Al2O3 is a suitable solvent-free approach to easily achieve P-modified Pt catalysts with increased dispersion and activity. Phosphorus content as well as modification temperature are varied to identify optimum synthesis conditions for the preparation of highly active dehydrogenation catalysts. Catalyst properties such as particle size distribution and electronic properties are evaluated. Solid state 31P NMR spectroscopy further elucidates the nature of phosphorus species in the catalysts and identifies distinctive features that can be found in highly active Pt-P/Al2O3 catalysts from different synthesis routes. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials γ-Al2O3 support material, with a surface area of 145 m2 g−1 (average pore size 14.4 nm, total pore volume 0.512 cm3 g−1), was calcined at 500 °C (10 K min−1) for 4 h in air flow before use. H2[PtCl6]∙6 H2O (38–40 % Pt, 99.9 %) was purchased from abcr GmbH and NaH2PO2 (≥ 99 %) from Merck KGaA. 2.2 Catalyst preparation For the preparation of Pt/Al2O3, Al2O3 was impregnated overnight (16 h) at room temperature with an aqueous solution of H2[PtCl6]∙6 H2O. After solvent evaporation at 80 °C and 150 mbar, the material was calcined for 2 h at 400 °C (10 °C min−1) in air and then reduced for 2 h at 440 or 600 °C in 10 % H2/N2 (500 mln min−1, heating in N2 at 10 K min−1) in a tubular furnace (Carbolite Gero GmbH & Co. KG). To obtain a P-modified catalyst Pt-P/Al2O3, the calcined Pt/Al2O3 was placed in a crucible in a tubular furnace (tube diameter 40 mm) downstream of a crucible containing NaH2PO2 (Fig. S1). The phosphorus modification was conducted in N2 (500 mln min−1, heating in N2 at 10 K min−1) at 300 or 600 °C for 2 h, with different initial molar P:Pt ratios. For example, an initial molar P:Pt ratio of approximately 2.4 corresponds to 250 mg NaH2PO2∙H2O and 1 g Pt/Al2O3 (3 wt% Pt). 2.3 ICP-OES Inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) was applied to determine phosphorus and platinum contents of the catalysts. 100 mg of each sample were digested using microwave heating (10 mL HNO3:HCl, v:v = 4:6, 200 °C) and diluted to 100 mL using deionized water. Emission spectra of the solutions were recorded on a Ciros CCD by SPECTRO Analytical Instruments GmbH. 2.4 N2 physisorption For the determination of textural properties (specific surface area and pore volume), N2 physisorption was conducted at −196 °C on a Quadrasorb SI by Quantachrome Instruments. To remove any residues from the surface before measurement the samples were degassed and dried for 12 h at 250 °C in vacuum (0.01 mbar). The BET method in a relative pressure range of 0.05–0.2 was applied to determine the specific surface area and the total pore volume was determined at p/p0 = 0.99. 2.5 Electron microscopy To determine particle size distributions, high-angle annular dark field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) combined with energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDXS) was conducted on a Talos F200i by Thermo Fisher Scientific. The projected areas of 150–200 particles were evaluated. The volume-averaged particle size d VA was calculated as d VA = ∑n i d i 3/∑n i d i 2, with n i the number of particles with diameter d i . 2.6 CO pulse chemisorption The CO adsorption behavior of the catalysts was investigated by CO pulse chemisorption experiments on an Autochem II 2920 by Micromeritics. The catalyst samples were pretreated in He (5 °C min−1, 50 mln min−1, 60 min at 250 °C for Pt-PH3/Al2O3) or in 10 % H2/Ar (5 °C min−1, 50 mln min−1, 60 min at 440 °C or 600 °C for Pt/Al2O3, 700 °C for Pt-H3PO3/Al2O3). Pulse chemisorption was conducted at 40 °C and with 10 % CO/He. The difference of dosed and not-adsorbed CO volume assuming ideal gas was used to calculate the adsorbed amount of CO. The dispersion and particle size of Pt was calculated assuming a stoichiometric factor of 1. 2.7 X-ray diffraction For the determination of the morphology of the catalysts, X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were measured on a Pananalytical X-Pert Pro-MD by Philips equipped with a Cu-Kα source (wavelength λ of 1.5406 Å). Recording was conducted in a range of 2θ from 10 ° to 90 ° with a scan speed of 0.02 ° s−1. 2.8 XPS To investigate electronic properties and oxidation states of platinum and phosphorus, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was conducted on a Kratos Analytical Axis Ultra DLD spectrometer with monochromatic Al Kα irradiation (1486.6 eV) and operating the anode at 10 kV with an aperture of 700 x 300 μm. The pass energy for survey scans was 160 eV and 20 eV for high-resolution spectra. C1s contribution of adventitious carbon at 284.8 eV was used to calibrate the energy axis. 2.9 Solid state 31P NMR Solid state 31P NMR spectra were acquired on a 500 MHz (11.7 T) DD2 Agilent wide-bore NMR spectrometer. Samples were packed into 1.6 mm zirconia rotors. 31P cross-polarization (CP) spectra were recorded at a MAS rate of 15 kHz. After a π/2 pulse of 2.5 μs on 1H, the RF of 1H was ramped from 58 to 80 kHz while the RF on 31P was kept constant at 76 kHz during a contact time of 4 ms (Hartmann-Hahn match). 100 kHz spinal-64 decoupling was applied on 1H during acquisition. Recycle delays were set to 3 s, 5000–10000 scans were recorded. DSS was used as indirect reference. 2.10 Catalytic testing For the evaluation of catalytic activity, semi-batch dehydrogenation experiments were conducted in a glass set-up consisting of a three-necked 100 mL flask, a two-neck attachment with a metallic hollow cylinder for catalyst storage, and a reflux condenser (schematic illustration of the set-up in Fig. S2). The experiments were performed using 15 g perhydro benzyltoluene (H12-BT, degree of hydrogenation 97.37 % or 100 %, obtained from hydrogenation of benzyltoluene [20], benzyltoluene by Eastman Chemical Company) and a molar H12-BT:Pt ratio of 2000. This corresponds to approximately 251 mg catalyst at 3 wt% Pt loading. The set-up was flushed with Ar while heating to the reaction temperature (250 °C, 1 atm). At 250 °C, the Ar flow was stopped, and the catalyst was dropped into the hot liquid. Liquid samples taken over the course of the reaction (six hours) were analyzed via refractive index measurements (DR6100-T by Krüss Optronic GmbH, calibrated with GC) and GC-FID (Shimadzu 2010 Plus; column Rxi-17Sil MS 30 m, 0,25 mm ID, 0.25 µm by Restek). To evaluate the performance of the catalyst, the platinum-based hydrogen yield and productivity were calculated using the degree of dehydrogenation (DoDh). The DoDh is defined as the ratio between the amount of released hydrogen and the amount of hydrogen that is potentially released at complete dehydrogenation, which corresponds to six H2 molecules per molecule perhydro benzyltoluene. The H2 yield YH2 in gH2 gPt −1 and productivity P in gH2 gPt −1 min−1 were determined from the DoDh (obtained from GC-FID) via Eq. 1 and Eq. 2. (1) Y H 2 = ∆ DoDh ∙ n H 12 − BT ∙ 12 m Pt (2) P = ( DoD h i − DoD h i − 1 ) ∙ n H 12 − BT ∙ 12 m Pt ∙ ( t i − t i − 1 ) Herein, ∆DoDh corresponds to the difference in degree of dehydrogenation before and after semi-batch dehydrogenation, n H12-BT to the molar amount of perhydro benzyltoluene and m Pt to the amount of platinum in gram. The number 12 reflects the number of moles of hydrogen that would be released by complete dehydrogenation per mole of H12-BT. The index i (or i-1, respectively) signifies the DoDh in the sample taken at time i (t i ). Detailed information on the evaluation of GC-FID data for the evaluation of side product formation is given in the supporting information. 3 Results Pt/Al2O3 catalysts with 3 wt% Pt content were P-modified in a tubular furnace by the decomposition of NaH2PO2 at different modification temperatures (300–600 °C). A modification temperature of 300 °C was selected as a minimum temperature necessary for the decomposition of NaH2PO2 to form gaseous PH3. [19] 600 °C was selected to compare with Pt catalysts that were obtained from wet impregnation with H3PO3 and subsequently reduced at 600 °C in our previous study [14]. Furthermore, unmodified Pt catalysts after 440 °C (standard for these catalysts [21,22]) and 600 °C (high temperature) reduction were considered for comparison. For the gas phase P-modification method, the final P content in the catalyst was tuned by the relative amount of precursor (NaH2PO2) to unmodified calcined Pt/Al2O3 catalyst (referred to as initial molar P:Pt ratio). Table 1 lists the catalysts investigated in this study, the applied synthesis conditions and resulting Pt and P contents. Only 12–50 % of the phosphorus from the precursor are found in the final catalyst. Differences between P-modification at 300 and 600 °C become evident at high initial molar P:Pt ratios (> 3). Approximately 70 % higher amounts of phosphorus were deposited on the catalyst at the higher modification temperature (600 °C). Usually, P-modification was performed without previous catalyst reduction. However, the P-modification method was also applied to a pre-reduced Pt/Al2O3 catalyst (catalyst 2-b*), which resulted in a similar composition as for the calcined Pt/Al2O3. P-modification of the pure Al2O3 support material was attempted with 250 mg NaH2PO2∙H2O and 1 g Al2O3, but only very low amounts of phosphorus (< 0.02 wt%) were deposited at both 300 and 600 °C (Table S1). The catalytic performance of these materials was investigated in semi-batch dehydrogenation of perhydro benzyltoluene (H12-BT). In a first set of experiments, we compared the influence of P content on the performance of catalyst series 2 (Pt-P300/Al2O3, P-modification at 300 °C) and catalyst series 3 (Pt-P600/Al2O3, P-modification at 600 °C). Ptred-P300/Al2O3 refers to catalyst 2-b* , which corresponds to P-modification at 300 °C of catalyst 1-a (reduced Pt/Al2O3). The integral Pt-based H2 yields after 6 h of reaction are displayed in Fig. 1. With catalyst series 2 (P-modification at 300 °C, Fig. 1a), integral H2 yields after 6 h of reaction ranged from 52 to 61 gH2 gPt −1 for all catalysts with molar P:Pt ratios from 0.5 to 1.6. The catalysts synthesized with an additional reduction step (catalyst 2-b*, open diamond) showed similar catalytic activity with respect to P-modified catalysts without reduction. Compared to the P-free Pt/Al2O3 catalyst reduced at 440 °C (open circle, 68 gH2 gPt −1 min−1), lower H2 yields were achieved. This is also reflected in the lower Pt-based hydrogen productivities over the whole range of DoDh (see Fig. S4 a). On the other hand, catalysts from P-modification at 600 °C (Fig. 1b, series 3) showed final H2 yields improved by up to 24 % (84 gH2 gPt −1 min−1) compared to the unmodified catalyst 1-a (Pt/Al2O3 reduced at 440 °C) and by even 83 % when compared to the P-free catalyst 1-b, that was also reduced at 600 °C. This performance boost by P-modification is observed over a broad range of molar P:Pt ratio between 0.6 and 2.6, resulting in overall higher Pt-based H2 productivities (Fig. S4 b). However, for P:Pt ratios beyond 3.8, the final H2 yield and productivity drop. The significant activity boost observed in the range of P:Pt = 0.6–2.6 even exceeds the performance of a Pt-catalyst that was modified by wet impregnation with H3PO3 (P:Pt = 1.8, red triangle), as described in our previous study [14]. The selectivity in the dehydrogenation of perhydro benzyltoluene was assessed by monitoring the content of methyl fluorene (MF) in the liquid phase. MF is formed upon cyclization and further release of H2 (Scheme 1) of benzyltoluene (H0-BT), which is the first step to the formation of higher aromatics and coke. These processes lead to a loss of the LOHC and catalyst deactivation. Therefore, MF is a good indicator for the formation of undesired side products [20]. Fig. 2 compares the MF formation for the P-free Pt catalysts with a gas phase (600 °C, catalyst 3-b) and liquid phase (H3PO3, red. 600 °C) P-modified catalyst. MF levels increased with increasing degree of dehydrogenation (DoDh), as it is formed in a consecutive reaction step from H0-BT. Both P-modified catalysts showed slightly increased MF levels compared to the P-free Pt/Al2O3 catalysts, pointing to a very high dehydrogenation activity that also promotes the further dehydrogenation beyond the desired product H0-BT. The formation of MF over P-promoted catalysts produced by the gas-phase (PH3) and liquid-phase (H3PO3) procedures are similar, and furthermore, there were no significant differences in MF formation within catalyst series 3 for P:Pt ratios between 0.6 and 2.6. Only at the highest molar P:Pt ratios of 3.8 and 4.7 (P loadings of 1.9 and 2.3 wt%, respectively), lower MF concentrations were observed along with a strongly reduced dehydrogenation activity (Fig. S5 b). P-modification at 300 °C resulted in MF formation curves that are comparable to the unmodified Pt catalysts, independent of the P content (Fig. S5 a). Because P-modification at 300 °C did not increase dehydrogenation activity of the catalysts, while P-modification at 600 °C results in a clearly higher activity, heating the catalyst to 600 °C leads to changes in the catalyst that seem critical to obtain the promoting effect of P. These changes may also be affected by the reducing properties of the gas atmosphere. To understand the impact of the temperature and gas atmosphere better, different post-treatment methods involving different temperatures using N2 or 10 % H2/N2 were investigated for an initial molar P:Pt ratio of 2.4 ( Table 2). Generally, with the Pt/Al2O3 materials being in the furnace with the P-precursor for twice as long (4 h instead of 2 h) compared to catalyst series 2 and 3, approximately twice as high final P contents were achieved at similar initial molar P:Pt ratios. The dehydrogenation results of these catalysts are compared to a P-free Pt catalyst reduced at 440 °C (1-a) and a 600 °C P-modified catalyst (P:Pt = 0.8, 3-b) in Fig. 3. A post-reduction in H2 at 400 °C (4-a) did not improve catalyst activity, instead, showing similar or lower H2 yield and productivity as catalyst series 2 (P-modification at 300 °C, see Fig. S6). Improved H₂ yields were achieved with post-treatments at 600 °C, reaching similar values to those of catalyst 3-b, regardless of the gas composition (H₂/N₂ or N₂, catalysts 4-b and 4-c, respectively) used in the post-treatment step or the final phosphorus (P) content. Interestingly, the formation of MF was on a similar level to that of catalyst 3-b (Fig. 3b). This means that a treatment step at 600 °C is crucial to achieve an activity boost in dehydrogenation. Since the observed high dehydrogenation activities despite reduction at 600 °C hint to an improved sinter stability of the active phase, STEM images of selected catalysts were recorded to investigate particle size distribution on the catalyst surface. With an increase in reduction temperature of the unmodified Pt catalysts [14] from 440 (catalyst 1-a) to 600 °C (catalyst 1-b), an increase of the average particle size from 1.1 to 5.8 nm can be observed along with a broadening of particle size distribution ( Fig. 4b). This increase in particle size corresponds to the well-known sintering of supported Pt nanoparticles on alumina at elevated temperatures [23,24]. In contrast, the sintering behavior of the P-promoted catalysts is different. Catalyst 2-b (Fig. S7), that was P-modified at 300 °C, exhibits smaller mean particle sizes (0.9 nm) than the unmodified counterparts. After P-modification at 600 °C (catalyst 3-b) similarly small particle sizes with an even narrower particle size distribution are obtained (Fig. 4a, c). A concentration of P around Pt could not be identified with certainty on the EDX spectrum images due to the high dispersion and small size of the Pt nanoparticles as well as the low P content. To identify potential interactions between Pt and P, the samples were further investigated with CO pulse chemisorption and XPS. The electronic environments of both elements can be probed by these techniques, which might further elucidate reasons for different catalytic activities despite similar particle sizes for catalysts that were P-modified at 300 and 600 °C. All particle sizes evaluated from CO pulse chemisorption ( Table 3) seem to be larger than the particle sizes obtained by STEM, which hints to a limited accessibility of Pt centers for CO adsorption. For the P-free catalysts 1-a and 1-b, the CO adsorption capacity was reduced by 78 % upon an increase in reduction temperature from 440 to 600 °C. P-modification at 300 °C resulted in an adsorption capacity of 312 mmolCO molPt −1 (catalyst 2-b), which was increased to 459 mmolCO molPt −1 upon increase of modification temperature to 600 °C at a similar P:Pt ratio (catalyst 3-b). A Pt-H3PO3/Al2O3 catalyst obtained from wet impregnation with H3PO3 and reduced at 600 °C showed similar CO chemisorption results as catalyst 3-b from gas phase P-modification at 600 °C. All catalysts that were P-modified at 600 °C and showed high dehydrogenation activity (catalyst 3-b to 3-f) gave similar CO adsorption capacities of approximately 500 ± 30 mmolCO molPt −1 regardless of their P content. On the other hand, the two less active catalysts with the highest molar P:Pt ratios of 3.8 and 4.6 (3-g and 3-h) showed drastically reduced CO adsorption capacities of 193 and 156 mmolCO molPt −1. Accordingly, the H2 productivity per available amount of Pt is highest for catalysts P-modified at 600 °C in the optimum P:Pt range (Fig. S8). Investigations of the different catalysts with XPS did not show any major differences in Al2p and O1s lines (Fig. S9, Fig. S10). The unmodified Pt catalyst (1-a) exhibits a Pt4d line located at 314.8 eV ( Fig. 5a), which is indicative of Pt0 [25–27]. The Pt4d line is observed at the same binding energy for the Pt-catalyst that was P-modified at 600 °C (catalyst 3-b) and the Pt catalyst that was reduced prior to P-modification (catalyst 2-b*). However, slightly higher binding energies (315.2 eV) are observed after P-modification at 300 °C only (catalyst 2-b). This hints to the presence of additional oxidized Pt2+ species [28] which forms upon calcination at 400 °C of H2[PtCl6] [29,30] and was not fully reduced to Pt0 during the P-modification procedure at 300 °C. The P2p line after P-modification at 300 °C (catalysts 2-b and 2-b*) is located at 133.8 eV and shifts to 134.4 eV after P-modification at 600 °C (Fig. 5b). These values indicate the presence of oxidized phosphorus species like phosphates or phosphites (POx) [31–33]. However, some oxidized species such as P2O5 or phosphoric acid can be excluded, as their binding energies are expected above 135 eV [33–35]. Furthermore, platinum phosphide PtP2 is excluded as it should appear at binding energies below 130 eV [25,36,37]. After P-modification at 300 °C and subsequent post-treatment at 600 °C in H2/N2 or in N2 (catalysts 4-b and 4-c, respectively), these catalysts show the presence of Pt0 at a binding energy of 314.8 eV, just like catalyst 3-b that was directly P-modified at 600 °C ( Fig. 6a). Similarly, the P2p line is also located at the same binding energy as catalyst 3-b (134.4 eV) indicating an electron-poor POx species, which distinguishes these catalysts from catalyst 2-b that was P-modified at only 300 °C (Fig. 6b). There is no hint for the presence of a phosphide phase after post-treatment at 600 °C. To get further insights into the crystal structure of the catalysts, XRD measurements were performed (Fig. S11). The diffraction patterns of P-modified catalysts did not show any reflections indicative of phosphides or phosphates. The Pt reflection [38] at 81 ° 2θ is visible only for the unmodified Pt/Al2O3 reduced at 600 °C due to formation of sufficiently large crystallites upon sintering. Solid state 31P Cross Polarization (CP) NMR spectra under Magic Angle Spinning (MAS) were recorded to identify the P species present on the catalyst surface after different modification methods and temperatures. To establish the trends of P-modification and possible influences of the support, we first investigated the signals after P-modification of bare Al2O3 ( Fig. 7a, Table S2). After impregnation with H3PO3 for 16 h and solvent removal at 80 °C, a peak with a maximum at 3 ppm is observed, which we assigned to H3PO3 [39]. The resonance was relatively narrow as compared to spectra of samples with high temperature treatment. Narrow resonances in solid-state NMR spectra of amorphous samples usually indicate species with a stronger mobility. It is therefore likely that remaining (or re-adsorbed) water on the alumina surface induces a certain mobility of a probably non-covalently bound P species. A broader shoulder around −1 ppm is observed, too, which may indicate surface-bound species. Upon treatment in N2 or H2/N2 flow, the 31P resonances generally become broader and shift to lower chemical shifts with increasing temperature. Upon treatment at 600 °C in N2, the center of this very broad resonance shifts to −7 ppm, but several narrower resonances around −4, −7 and −10 ppm indicate the formation of defined P species. In the sample treated at 600 °C in H2/N2, additionally a narrower resonance at 3 ppm occurs, which again may stem from mobile H3PO3 on the surface (possibly induced by water re-adsorption). Since gas phase P-modification of Al2O3 with PH3 (by the decomposition of NaH2PO2) resulted in almost negligible adsorption of P onto the support, the signal to noise ratio of these spectra is extremely low. However, even in these spectra (P300/Al2O3 and P600/Al2O3) with weak signal, the narrow resonance of H3PO3 is visible after treatment at 300 °C and a broader, upfield resonance upon increase in temperature to 600 °C is visible. We then investigated P-modified Pt/Al2O3 materials by solid-state 31P CP MAS NMR spectroscopy (Fig. 7b, Table S2). The presence of Pt on Al2O3 resulted in the deposition of significantly higher amounts of P compared to the bare support, as shown earlier (Table 1). This indicates the preferred and strong interaction of the gaseous P precursor (PH3) with Pt. Likewise, the 31P CP MAS NMR spectra of these samples (green lines in Fig. 7b) show strong 31P resonances. As a general trend, in all samples, the presence of Pt on the alumina leads to a broader distribution of chemical shifts, and overall lower chemical shift values for otherwise comparable conditions. P species on alumina supports have been investigated in a previous study that combined solid-state NMR spectroscopy and Density Functional Theory calculations for similar systems of γ-Al2O3 impregnated with phosphate from aqueous solution. Based on this, broad resonances were attributed to a distribution of phosphate species which are either adsorbed on the surface or covalently bound to Al2O3 with up to three Al-O-P bonds [40]. Resonances at low chemical shifts down to −20 ppm were correlated with the formation of bi- or polyphosphates on the alumina surface. Note that in the present study, the oxidation state of P surface species is less well defined. Phosphates (oxidation state of P: V), but also less oxidized species may be present on the surface, as indicated by XPS (Fig. 5 and Fig. 6). The very low 31P chemical shifts in samples impregnated with H3PO3 indicate that mostly polyphosphates and covalently bound phosphates seem to be present. The presence of Pt and non-reducing gas flow (N2) induces the lowest chemical shifts, which we correlate to high P oxidation states and the formation of polymeric species. The formation of an AlPO4 phase is known to lead to a resonance at −32 ppm, which is not the case here [41]. In contrast, gas phase P-modification of Pt/Al2O3 with PH3 leads to resonances centered around −10 ppm, indicating the absence of polymeric species and probably, higher overall electron density of P. Additionally, some samples exhibit a weak, very narrow resonance at 0.8 ppm, which cannot be unambiguously assigned. A likely attribution would be a hydrated, mobile P species such as H3PO3 or H3PO4, which form upon re-equilibration of the samples with water from the atmosphere. Overall, the 31P MAS NMR hint to the presence of both surface-bound and mobile oxidized P species (POx), which interact with the Pt on the catalyst surface. 4 Discussion The presented characterization results allow us to follow the P-modification process of the Pt/Al2O3-catalyst. First, NaH2PO2 decomposes to PH3 in a furnace, already at temperatures of 300 °C. The formed PH3 interacts via the gas-phase with the catalyst material. ICP-OES results of our materials that have undergone this PH3 treatment (gas phase P-modification) show that P was hardly deposited on pure Al2O3. Only the presence of Pt promoted the significant deposition of phosphorus species on the catalyst surface, indicating that initial interaction of the catalyst with gaseous PH3 proceeds via the Pt surface. XPS investigations of the P2p line revealed the presence of oxidized P species such as phosphates or phosphites on all prepared catalysts, demonstrating that after interaction of PH3 with Pt, the P precursor gets oxidized (loses electron density). For catalysts with a high P-loading the formation of oxidic phosphate phases was also observed in XRD. As the treatment is performed under reductive atmosphere, we suggest oxygen from the Al2O3-support or possibly also PtO to be responsible for the oxidation of P-species, presumably at the interphase between Pt-nanoparticle and Al2O3-support. However, following stoichiometric relations, the amount of O-atoms that stem from PtO are not enough to fully oxidize the P-species available, why further oxygen sources, such as oxygen from the support material must contribute to POx formation. Consequently, after the first contact of PH3 with Pt, the P-species moves to the support, where it gets oxidized. Treatment of the catalyst at higher temperatures of 600 °C, either under N2 or H2/N2 enable this movement, while temperatures of 400 °C or below are not sufficient, as concluded from the post-treatment experiments in Table 2 and Fig. 3. Note, that XPS and XRD measurement do not hint to the formation of a phosphide phase, which is quite remarkable when considering that the oxidation state of –III in the applied P precursor (PH3) is similar to what one would expect for a phosphide. In our studies, we prepared the P-modification at two temperatures: 300 °C and 600 °C. The P2p lines of all catalysts that were P-modified at only 300 °C exhibited a lower binding energy (133.8 eV), compared to catalysts from P-modification at 600 °C, where the P2p line was located at higher binding energy (134.4 eV), i.e., lower electron density at phosphorus. Following this observation, the intermediate oxidation state of the P-species is higher in the 600 °C treated catalysts. The final amount of phosphorus deposited on the catalyst can be easily tuned instead by adjusting the initial P:Pt ratio (relative precursor amount) in the furnace. However, also the treatment temperature has an influence on the P deposition. If the P-treatment proceeds at 600 °C instead of 300 °C the ICP-OES investigations reveal a higher amount of P deposited on the catalysts. In accordance, CO pulse chemisorption measurements show, that also the active metal surface area, available for CO binding is higher, if the catalysts are treated at 600 °C. Most probably P-species block a higher share of Pt atoms after treatment at 300 °C only, while the 600 °C seem to increase their mobility to move from the Pt particle to the support interface. In that way, Pt surface centers are liberated and able to bind more CO. This facilitated movement of P-species and Pt-liberation also allows the adsorption of further PH3 during the modification process, explaining the higher final P-content in the 600 °C treated catalysts. However, upon an increase in P content beyond the optimum range (max. P:Pt 2.6), due to their high abundance around the Pt particles, the POx species cannot be transported away (even at 600 °C) and additionally cover active Pt sites, blocking the catalyst. Platinum is partially oxidized in the Pt/Al2O3 starting material, as the examination of the Pt4d line in XPS reveals. Platinum is reduced to Pt0 after treating the catalyst with PH3 at 600 °C, even without an additional reduction step in H2/N2. This indicates that the reducing power of PH3 is high enough at elevated temperatures of 600 °C for a full reduction of Pt2+ to Pt0. At 300 °C in contrast, only PH3 treatment at 300 °C was not sufficient to fully reduce the Pt2+, making an additional treatment in H2/N2 before or afterwards necessary to reach Pt0 on the surface. Our STEM investigations show that these reduced Pt forms nanoparticles with small intermediate sizes after P-modification at both temperature stages. Surprisingly no sintering is observed even after treatment at 600 °C. Our results even show that Pt particle sizes were slightly reduced below 1 nm after PH3 treatment (compared to the starting material). This finding demonstrates, that the POx species present at the interphase between Pt and Al2O3 introduce a sinter-stabilizing effect to the material. Results from solid state 31P CP MAS NMR provide a deeper insight into the state of the P species, after their transfer to the support surface. To specifically investigate the interaction between oxidized P-species and Al2O3, first without the presence of Pt, the support was impregnated with H3PO3. When the treatment temperature of these impregnated samples was increased from 300 to 600 °C, an upfield shift of the peaks was observed in 31P CP MAS NMR. This is tentatively attributed to the deposition and possibly covalent binding of more oxidized P species on the support and condensation of PO4 tetrahedra at higher temperatures [42,43]. For the PH3-modified Pt/Al2O3 catalysts, a similar trend of an upfield shift upon temperature increase was observed. At the same time, resonances at −20 ppm were absent in the PH3-treated sample, which indicates less interaction of POx-species to form polyphosphates and hints towards a better dispersion of P species in these samples. The high temperature treatment at 600 °C favors the oxidation and the covalent binding of P species to the support, which is reflected in the results from 31P CP MAS NMR as well as XPS (reduction of electron density at P). Overall, the 31P MAS NMR hint to the presence of both surface-bound and mobile oxidized P species (POx), which interact with the Pt on the catalyst surface. These POx species at the interphase between support and Pt nanoparticle enable the confinement of the latter and avoid the nanoparticle sintering even at high temperatures. The P-modified Pt-catalysts of this study were tested in the dehydrogenation of perhydro benzyltoluene. Compared to the P-free Pt/Al2O3 catalyst, a higher catalytic activity was observed after PH3-treatment at a temperature of 600 °C. One reason for the higher activity after PH3-treatment at 600 °C compared to the P-free material surely lies in the smaller intermediate particle size, determined by STEM. However, despite similarly small particle sizes after P-modification at 300 and 600 °C, no activity boost in dehydrogenation was observed for the 300 °C method, which indicates that only the presence of small nanoparticles after PH3 modification is not sufficient for high dehydrogenation activity. Also, the dehydrogenation boost was not observed for catalysts that were P-modified at 300 °C, regardless of a reduction step included before P-modification, ruling out that insufficient reduction of Pt would be a possible cause for the low dehydrogenation activity. In contrast, this loss in electron density (oxidation) of phosphorus upon 600 °C treatment is a common denominator for the highly active Pt-P/Al2O3 dehydrogenation catalysts, as seen in the XPS studies. This can be explained by the higher share of oxidized P-species in these catalysts, coming from a more pronounced interaction with the support material. Hence, more P is transported to the support interphase, instead of blocking Pt atoms for the dehydrogenation reaction. This approach to explain the activity boost by P-modification after 600 °C treatment is supported, when comparing our results from CO pulse chemisorption and STEM. Despite their smaller particle size that was observed in microscopy, the CO adsorption capacity was lower for all P-modified catalysts compared to an unmodified Pt catalyst (reduced at 440 °C). When the Pt particle size is calculated from these CO adsorption data, an opposite trend compared to STEM determined particle size is observed. To solve this contradiction we suggest that P species on the catalyst are in close interaction with platinum, influencing the accessibility of some Pt sites for CO. However, under reaction conditions the P-blocking of the active centers in the 600°C-treated catalyst does not appear to be so pronounced, as a higher activity compared to the P-free catalyst is observed for P:Pt < 2.6. Only if even more P is deposited on the catalyst (P:Pt ratios of 3.8 and 4.6) a simultaneous drop in CO capacity and dehydration activity can be detected. Also catalysts that were P-modified at 300 °C show low activity in dehydrogenation and low CO capacity in chemisorption experiments. Therefore, we assume an increased blockage of Pt sites by P species, when the catalyst was not heated to > 300 °C during or after P-modification of if the capacity of the neighboring Al2O3 sites to bind more POx species is fully utilized and does not allow for further removal of P-species for the Pt surface. 5 Conclusion In this study, we presented a solvent-free phosphorus-modification method for Al2O3 supported Pt catalysts to obtain highly active dehydrogenation catalysts. 3 wt% Pt/Al2O3 catalysts were modified with phosphorus by decomposition of the precursor NaH2PO2 to PH3 in a furnace. The high catalytic activity in dehydrogenation of perhydro benzyltoluene was boosted by up to 24 % with respect to a non-modified Pt/Al2O3 catalyst and was further reflected in the increased formation of methyl fluorene. The highest activities were measured over a range of P:Pt from 0.6 to 2.6. We could further prove narrow particle size distributions and small average particle sizes (0.9 nm) for the gas phase P-modified Pt catalysts despite synthesis temperatures as high as 600 °C. By applying XPS, 31 P CP MAS NMR, STEM, CO pulse chemisorption and XRD, the stepwise mechanism of P-modification and the relationship between the treatment conditions and catalytic activity could be revealed. The mechanism of P-modification of the Pt/Al2O3 catalyst involves the interaction of PH3 (formed from NaH2PO2) with the Pt surface, promoting phosphorus deposition. Phosphorus species are oxidized in the next step, likely using oxygen from the Al2O3 support or oxidized Pt species (e.g. PtO). At higher treatment temperatures (600 °C), the P species migrate from Pt surface to the support/metal interphase, liberating the Pt surface again for further PH3-adsorption. This migration process also prevents Pt particle sintering, with the POx species acting as stabilizers, indicated by the close interaction between POx-species and Pt that was observed in XPS and solid state 31P NMR studies. However, when the P-amount in the neighborly Al2O3 of the Pt-particle exceeds the capacity of the support (P:Pt > 2.6) further removal of P-species from the Pt surface is hampered, what results in a poisoning of the active centers. A too low treatment temperature of 300 °C also restricts the mobility of the P-species, leading to a blocking of the active centers in similar way. coredata.dc:description: This study introduces a solvent-free gas-phase method for modifying Al₂O₃-supported platinum (3 wt%) catalysts with phosphorus (P) to enhance Pt dispersion and dehydrogenation activity. The process involves decomposing NaH₂PO₂ at 600 °C, releasing PH₃, interacting with Pt on the catalyst surface. P-modified catalysts showed up to a 24 % increase in activity for perhydro-benzyltoluene dehydrogenation within a P:Pt ratio of 0.6–2.6. Additionally, they exhibited high resistance to sintering, maintaining Pt particle sizes of ∼0.9 nm even at 600 °C. Characterization using CO chemisorption, STEM NMR, and XPS revealed that PH₃ deposits phosphorus on the catalyst, which then oxidizes via support lattice oxygen. At 600 °C, this oxidized phosphorus migrates to the support/metal interface, stabilizing Pt nanoparticles and preventing sintering. However, when the P:Pt ratio exceeds 2.6, excess phosphorus remains on the surface, deactivating active sites. This study highlights the role of POₓ species in stabilizing Pt nanoparticles and optimizing catalyst performance.
